reviews.review_msg: She is very rude and aggressive. She will not at all help you in the class or ouside the class.
Best professor at SFU. If you have the opportunity to take a class this her. Take it! Great feedback.

Dr. Chin was a decent prof. Her exams are very specific and require recalling random facts. Aside from the unnecessary difficulty of exams she is actually really good at explaining difficult concepts and makes herself accessible outside of class help over email in her own time. Attend class as she gives hints as to what will be on the exam.

She is a great professor. You have to attend every lecture and take all the notes beside lecture notes because only 30% material is provided in lecture slide. The exam is easy if you memorize everything she gave you. And I got A- in this course.

PROS: - organized CONS: - reads off slides, not engaging - wordy but redundant notes, slow to main point - randomly selected exam questions; you will overstudy and understudy some topics - tutorial presentations mandatory but poor use of TA time - exam prep is weak: no practice exams ready, no post exam review sessions

Her slides make it really obvious what you should know for the exam, & she gives example exam questions. You need to show up because she uses the overhead for notes that go with the slides, & that info is also fair game on exams. Marking criteria is clearly listed, & she lets you hand in a draft of the project so she can help you not lose marks.

The content is super interesting and very informative. She is very clear and organized. The only reason she sent 20 emails is to answer the students asking silly questions (i.e. "do I need to actually have sources in my scientific paper") This class isn't handed to you, you need to study. Tests had some hard questions for sure.

I am coming to class to be taught, not have a video put on while she relaxes as if this is some expensive daycare rather than university. Dr Chin is a terrible prof, she is unclear and rude.  If you are an involved student who wants to succeed she will not help you, in fact she will send excessive emails in caps explaining nothing.

Worst prof I've never had. The content is interesting but she's very unorganized and her midterms are nothing like how she said they'll be. The midterms are not fair and it's very hard to do well in this course. Don't suggest it if you don't need to take it.

This was Dr. Chin's first time teaching MBB 321, and I think she did it very well. She drops LOTS of hints for the exams during lecture. She makes it very clear what you need to do to do well on the exam.

She is unorganized, and lecture heavy. Eunice doesn't try to explain topics, just reads directly off her slides(posts them 1 day or 2 after lecture). The written test format and answers require too many details to possibly remember. 2 midterms(noncumulative) and a cumulative final. Your bio 12 grade isn't even relevant to what grade to expect.

She's not good!! For the lab final, she told students to study out of the lab manual and know the SLO and challenge questions. The exam is nothing like what she tells you to study! Also her exams are straight off lecture slides! If u miss a word off slide in your answer, you will get marks taken off. Overall, bad experience! Avoid her if u can

The worst prof I have had so far at SFU. Lectures very heavy and prof was very unclear about midterms and finals; wouldn't specify what was on.  Read off lecture slides every class and would say everythings on the final/midterm. Just not a good prof overall

So many passive aggressive emails sent out to the class. Very tough grader- marks exactly from lecture slides, so if you're missing one bold word you lose a mark even if you had the right idea, marks taken off for spelling words wrong (even ones unrelated to the subject in any way).
she's very unclear about expectations for finals and midterms

Sends 2-4 passive aggressive emails a week scolding students for "rumours". Gives no feedback with grades (only know midterm marks before going into final). Focuses on very small details and marks incredibly hard. Tells you to focus on things then doesn't put them on the exam. Completely ruined my passion and love for biology. Avoid at all costs!!!

Lectures were spent typing as fast as possible to try and get all the notes down while she rushed through them, reading everything off of the slides. Slides were only posted after lecture, so no pre-reading could be done. Labs were horribly structured. Exams were fair, but toughly marked. I'd recommend taking this course with a different professor.
Avoid this class at all costs. worse prof ever, tested hard all written and lectures are really boring.

Honestly, If you enjoy biology and are passionate about it, do not take bisc 101 with Eunice. She made everything so boring, her 2 hour lectures were so dry they seemed like they lasted days. Midterms were alright, final was hell. Do not take with this prof.

Professor Eunice Chin has a good heart but is a terrible Professor when it comes to BISC 101. She  taught a 100 level course like a 300 level course and read everything off her lecture slides. If your still deciding whether to make your major or minor biology, do not take Eunice chin for a prof because she will Make you hate biology

You may want a tutor on the side... she just reads off lecture slides, and doesn't explain things too well... she'll tell u don't read the textbook! Honestly, read it! It will save your life. This is for BISC101
You may want a tutor on the side... she just reads off lecture slides, and doesn't explain things too well... she'll tell u don't read the textbook! Honestly, read it! It will save your life
Wouldn't take this professor unless you are a genius at memorzation. Have to be VERY specific on tests otherwise you lose many marks even though you have the main idea. I would not recommend.

Shes awful. Wish she would just give the complete slides and let us actually listen and understand the material in class. When students do listen and ask a question, she does not have the knowledge to answer it a lot of the times. She reads off her own laptop notes because even she cant memorize it all. Expect us to memorize a dictionary for exams.

So she was pretty bad. She did not know the material, it came straight out of the text. So if you wanted more info, she couldn't really answer it. She didn't tell you what to focus on, so you literally studied every detail. Her marking was brutal too; looked for specific words and terms even if you had the idea down.

She is way better than another instructor who teaches physics aspect of this course. you can't listen in lecture because she keeps people busy writing overhead notes (filling blanks). Term papers!!! not fair marking at all and for 3 credit course i think its too much work to have both presentation and term paper! & tutorials not helpful at all

Worst prof I've had in university. Notes were constantly changining and eventually we got stacks of fill in the blank notes which made it impossible to listen. Midterms were okay but marked strangely & feedback was ambiguous. (Never went over midterm answers in tutorials.) Also gave a term paper which is unheard of for this course. Avoid this prof.

Nice prof and pretty clear and helpful if you ask for it. She gives you a lot of detail in her answers and provides a lot of feedback. There's lots to memorize so over all but material isn't difficult. However she's REALLY nit picky about spelling and exact terms and phrases on exams. She destroyed people on the term papers, TA was more generous.

compared to other 305 profs she's one who focuses  barely at all on physics, a definite plus.  I would compare the information load to an MBB class though - a lot of memorization and very dry.  She is a good lecturer in that she shares slides, recordings, pages from the textbook, and writes notes as she goes.  only downside  tonne of information

Her first midterm was way too hard and basically the rest of the semester was trying to make it up because she wouldn't scale it. The other midterm and the final weren't too bad but there was no way to make up for the first midterm for most people. It was also hard to read her; she wasn't very clear on which topics were likely to be on tests.
